snippet.title: Friday night tram stabbing rampage in Footscray caught on smartphone
snippet.content:
Dramatic video footage has emerged of the moments after a man pulled out a knife and stabbed two passengers on a tram in Footscray on Friday night. Footage filmed on a bystander's smartphone shows a man, who has been dragged from the stationary route 82 tram, lying in the middle of Geelong Road as a witness uses a piece of clothing to apply pressure to what is believed to be a stab wound.

Two men stabbed on Footscray tram
Dramatic video footage has emerged of the moments after a man pulled out a knife and stabbed two men on a tram in Footscray on Friday night. Vision courtesy Seven News, Melbourne.
A police siren can be heard blaring in the background before officers can be seen rushing to the man's aid. A panicked witnesses can be heard asking one of the police officers if the offender was "still on the loose". "So we were on the tram and somebody has just stood up and stabbed somebody," another witness can be heard saying on her phone. The video was shared on Reddit before it was taken off the site early on Tuesday morning.
Police said the men, aged in their 20s, were on a tram heading north along Droop Street at the intersection of Geelong Road when the stabbing occurred. An Ambulance Victoria spokeswoman said paramedics were called to Geelong Road just before 9pm following reports of multiple stabbings.

She said a man, aged in his 20s, was treated at the scene for upper body wounds before being taken to the Royal Melbourne Hospital in a stable condition. Another man, aged in his 20s, was also taken to the Footscray Hospital with upper body wounds, in a stable condition. The offender fled down Geelong Road. Victoria Police said in a statement that the transit crime investigation unit arrested a 56-year-old man on Monday in relation to a stabbing incident at 8.45pm on Friday. The man has not been charged yet, but remains in custody and is currently assisting police with enquiries. Police urge anyone with information or who may have witnessed the incident to contact Crime Stoppers on 1800 333 000. More to come.
